Description: Amuletic pendant in the form of a crescent, made of dark blue glass; possibly moulded; small loop for suspension pierced widthways on top; complete.
Curator's comments: This type of amulet is associated to the protection of the moon god and is particularly popular in the Roman period (Petrie 1914, 23, pl. VI no. 85, especially very closed specimens 85 a-b in pale blue glass but dated to the 18th Dynasty). Crescent pendants are also common on necklaces of the Classical world (Davidson and Oliver 1984, 76-7, no. 74). For a Roman parallel: Dublin 2007, 56. Davidson, P. F. and Oliver, A. 1984, Ancient Greek and Roman gold jewelry in the Brooklyn Museum, Wilbour monographs 8, New York. Dubin, L. S. 2007. The history of beads: from 30,000 B.C. to the present, London. Petrie, W.M.F. 1914, Amulets, London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (Pl. XX, no. 24)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.367) (phase 3)
